title: British backpacker, 25, fell 650ft to her death while climbing down waterfall
text:
A British backpacker plummeted 650 feet to her death after attempting to climb down a waterfall during a solo night-time trek in Peru.

Elizabeth Orchard's body was discovered almost a week after she plunged into a deep ravine during the hike through the Yanachaga-Chemillen National Park, an inquest heard today.

The 25-year-old was trekking through the South American forest with sister Rachel Orchard and her sister's boyfriend Calum Jones.

Elizabeth Orchard, 25, plummeted 650 feet to her death after attempting to climb down a waterfall during a solo night-time trek through the Yanachaga-Chemillen National Park in Peru

The tired couple retreated back to their hostel with blisters on their feet, but Elizabeth continued on her own.

Elizabeth, described as being 'full of energy' before splitting from the pair, believed she was just 20 minutes from the top of a path which she was determined to reach before nightfall.

Loved ones raised the alarm and an extensive hunt was launched after the environmental volunteer, also known as Lizzie, failed to return back to her room at the hostel later that evening.

Up to 50 police officers, joined by rescue coordinators, scoured the forest for signs of life after the alert was raised when Elizabeth did not return to her room at the hostel

The inquest heard how Elizabeth was excited to show the picture-perfect 'jurassic' locations she had discovered during her solo trek with the couple and told them the trip would feel like a 'time-warp back to the age of the dinosaurs'. Pictured: A valley in the Yanachaga-Chemillen National Park

Her parents Rupert and Cecilia - who live in a £650,000 home in the village of Grateley, near Andover, Hampshire, - immediately flew out to Peru after hearing of their daughter's disappearance.

Up to 50 police officers, joined by firefighters and park rangers, scoured the forest for signs of life but discovered Elizabeth's clothed body at the bottom of the ravine six days later.

Assistant Coroner Ian Singleton recorded a conclusion of accidental death at the inquest in Salisbury, Wiltshire.

He said: 'In the absence of any response, Rachel and Calum went back to their hostel, hoping Lizzie would be there already or would appear the next day.

'After an extensive search in difficult terrain, Lizzie's body was found in a ravine at the bottom of a long drop, adjacent to a route known as Orchid Way.

'Lizzie had been trying to climb down the side of a waterfall in circumstances that may well have been dark.'

She was trekking through the South American forest with sister Rachel Orchard and her sister's boyfriend Calum Jones. When the couple went back to their hostel, Elizabeth continued alone

The inquest heard how Elizabeth had explored the beautiful national park alone on May 30 before meeting her sister and her partner the following day.

She was excited to show the picture-perfect 'jurassic' locations she had discovered during her solo trek with the couple and told them the trip would feel like a 'time-warp back to the age of the dinosaurs'.

In a statement read to the court, Rachel said: 'Elizabeth described the fireflies and the stars as being incredible but that it had got much colder than she expected.'

Ms Orchard's parents, sister, brother and two uncles were in court.

In a statement, the family said: 'We are very sad to have lost a much loved daughter and sister. However, we are relieved to know how she died.

'We would like to take this opportunity to thank all those who have supported us throughout this difficult time, including the authorities in Peru and the Foreign & Commonwealth Office, as well as our extended family and many friends.

'We now ask that our privacy be respected and that we be allowed to grieve in peace.'
description: Elizabeth Orchard, 25, was trekking through the through the Yanachaga-Chemillen National Park in Pasco, Peru, with sister Rachel and her sister's boyfriend when Elizabeth decided to continue alone.
